example_thread:
3 years ago, I quit a $150k job to start a company with $0 in savings.

Everyone thought I was crazy.

Here's what actually happened ðŸ§µ

Some context:

I was 28, no kids, renting an apartment.

I'd been thinking about starting something for 5 years.

But there was always a reason to wait.

The trigger:

My manager rejected a project I'd worked on for 6 months.

Not because it was bad. Because it 'wasn't a priority anymore.'

I realized I'd never control my work inside a company.

Month 1-3:

I burned through my small savings fast.

No product. No customers. Just an idea.

I picked up freelance work to survive.

10 hour days minimum.

The lowest point:

Month 4. $400 in my account.

I almost called my old boss.

Instead, I sent 50 cold emails offering consulting.

3 replied. 1 became a $5k contract.

The turning point:

That client introduced me to their network.

Within 2 months, I had more work than I could handle.

I hired my first contractor.

Month 12:

- $180k revenue
- 3 contractors
- A real product in development
- More fulfilled than ever

Not wealthy. But free.

3 years later:

We're a team of 8.

The company nearly died twice.

But I've never once regretted quitting.

Not because of the money. Because of the ownership.

The lesson:

There's never a 'right time.'

If you're waiting for certainty, you'll wait forever.

The best time to start is when you're scared but ready.

What's the thing you've been putting off? ðŸ‘‡
tips: End with a lesson that applies broadly
